children.value: During today’s lesson it’s demonstrated how you to handle Temperature influences, stiffness discontinuities and support settlement for statically indeterminate structures.
To look at the temperature influences, it’s easier to look at a statically determinate structure. We could look at the statically determinate structure with the unknown statical indeterminate force

children.html: BvB_\text{v}Bv​

children.value: with the condition that the displacement at

children.html: B\text{B}B

children.value: Let’s focus on the displacement due to the temperature influence first. As the top is warmer than the bottom of the beam, the top of the beam will extend with respect to the bottom side. For the statically determinate beam this will lead to a deflection downwards:

children.html: κT\kappa^\text{T}κT
αΔTh=0.001 1m\alpha \cfrac{\Delta T}{h} = 0.001 \text{ }\frac{1}{\text{m}}αhΔT​=0.001 m1​

children.value: (◠), which is constant over the full beam:
The kinematically equivalent moment distribution has a couple at

children.html: B\text{B}B

children.value: of which the value follows from

children.html: M=κ⋅EI=6 kNmM = \kappa \cdot EI = 6 \text{ kNm}M=κ⋅EI=6 kNm

children.value: Using the forget-me-nots, this leads to a displacement at

children.html: B\text{B}B
M⋅L22EI=18 mm\cfrac{M \cdot L ^2}{2 EI} = 18 \text{ mm}2EIM⋅L2​=18 mm

children.value: Displacement due to statically indeterminate support reaction

children.label: Displacement due to statically indeterminate support reaction

children.value: If we only consider the statically indeterminate support reaction:
The displacement can be calculated as

children.label: Solve for statically indeterminate support reaction

BvB_\text{v}Bv​
18=3250Bv18 = \cfrac{3}{250}B_\text{v}18=2503​Bv​
Bv=1.5 kN (↑)B_\text{v} = 1.5 \text{ kN (↑)}Bv​=1.5 kN (↑)

children.value: The curvature due to the temperature influence doesn’t cause internal stresses. However, the support reactions does. This gives the following moment distribution:
The full displacement can be found by applying the forget-me-nots, leading to:

The displacement can be incorporated in the calculation using the force- or displacement method. This structure is solved using ‘hoekveranderingsvergelijkingen’, leading to the following statically determinate structure:
The positive rotations are defined as follows:
The first displacement condition can be filled in using forget-me-nots. The support settlement is taken into account as a (real) displacement and thus rotation:

children.html: φBAB=φBBC−MB⋅43⋅EI+17⋅4324⋅EI−wB4=MB⋅63⋅EI−MC⋅66⋅EI+wB6\begin{array}{c} \varphi _{\rm{B}}^{{\rm{AB}}} = \varphi _{\rm{B}}^{{\rm{BC}}}\\ \cfrac{{ - {M_{\rm{B}}} \cdot 4}}{{3 \cdot EI}} + \cfrac{{17 \cdot {4^3}}}{{24 \cdot EI}} - \cfrac{{{w_{\rm{B}}}}}{4} = \cfrac{{{M_{\rm{B}}} \cdot 6}}{{3 \cdot EI}} - \cfrac{{{M_{\rm{C}}} \cdot 6}}{{6 \cdot EI}} + \cfrac{{{w_{\rm{B}}}}}{6} \end{array}φBAB​=φBBC​3⋅EI−MB​⋅4​+24⋅EI17⋅43​−4wB​​=3⋅EIMB​⋅6​−6⋅EIMC​⋅6​+6wB​​​

children.value: The second displacement condition gives similarly:

children.html: φC=0−MB⋅63⋅EI=MC⋅66⋅EI+wB6=0\begin{array}{c} \varphi_\text{C} = 0 \\ -\cfrac{M_\text{B} \cdot 6}{3 \cdot EI} = \cfrac{M_\text{C} \cdot 6}{6 \cdot EI} + \cfrac{w_\text{B}}{6} = 0 \end{array}φC​=0−3⋅EIMB​⋅6​=6⋅EIMC​⋅6​+6wB​​=0​

children.value: Solving this system of two equation gives:

children.html: MB=−128kNmM_\text{B} = -128 \text{kNm}MB​=−128kNm
MC=−132 kNmM_\text{C} = -132 \text{ kNm}MC​=−132 kNm

children.value:
import sympy as sym

alpha, L, Delta_T, h = sym.symbols('alpha, L, Delta_T, h')
EI = sym.symbols('EI')

alpha = sym.nsimplify(10**-5)
Delta_T = 20
EI = 6000
L = 6
h = sym.nsimplify(0.2)

kappa = alpha * Delta_T / h
display(kappa)

M = kappa * EI
display(M)

w = M * L**2 / EI / 2
display(w)

F = w * 3 * EI / L **3 
display(F)

Bv = sym.symbols('Bv')
display( Bv * L **3 / EI / 3 )

M_A = F * L
display(M_A)

w_halfway = M * (L/2)**2 / EI / 2
display(w_halfway)

w_halfway_2 = F * L/2 * (L/2)**2 / EI / 2 + F * (L/2)**3 / 3 / EI
display(w_halfway_2)

x = sym.symbols('x')
w_halfway = M * (x)**2 / EI / 2 -  F * (L-x) * (x)**2 / EI / 2 - F * (x)**3 / 3 / EI

sym.plot(w_halfway, (x, 0, L))

display(w_halfway.subs(x, L/2))

M_C, M_D, w_B = sym.symbols('M_C, M_D, w_B')

EI = 34000

w_B = sym.nsimplify(24 / 1000)

eq1 = sym.Eq(-M_C * 4 / EI / 3 + sym.nsimplify(4**3) * 17 / 24 / EI - w_B / 4, M_C * 6 / 3 / EI - M_D * 6 / 6 / EI + w_B / 6)
eq2 = sym.Eq(-M_C * 6 / EI / 6 + M_D * 6 / 3 / EI + w_B / 6, 0)

sol = sym.solve([eq1, eq2], (M_C, M_D))
display(sol)
We’ll investigate the influence of the stiffness of the right part.
Let’s start with a high stiffness, so

children.html: MB=nn+1 316 FLM_\text{B} = \cfrac{n}{n+1} \ \cfrac{3}{16} \ FLMB​=n+1n​ 163​ FL
Mat F=(−nn+1 316+14)FLM_{\text{at }F} = \left(-\cfrac{n}{n+1} \ \cfrac{3}{16} + \cfrac{1}{4} \right) FLMat F​=(−n+1n​ 163​+41​)FL

children.value: This leads to the following diagrams:

children.html: n=0n=0n=0
n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞

children.value: the moments approach the extreme values obtained before.

import numpy as np
%config InlineBackend.figure_formats = ['svg']
n = np.linspace(0, 50, 1000)
M_B = n / (n+1) * 3/16
M_C = -n / (n+1) * 3/16 + 1/4

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.plot(n, M_B, label='$M_B$')
# get color of last line
line = plt.gca().lines[-1]
color = line.get_color()
plt.plot([0, 50], [3/16,3/16], '--',color=color)

plt.plot(n, M_C, label='$M_{at \ F}$')
line = plt.gca().lines[-1]
color = line.get_color()
plt.plot([0, 50], [-3/16+1/4,-3/16+1/4], '--',color=color)
plt.xlim([0,50])
plt.xlabel('$n$')
plt.ylabel('$M \ (/{FL})$')
ax = plt.gca()
ax.spines['right'].set_color('none')
ax.spines['top'].set_color('none')
ax.spines['bottom'].set_position('zero')
ax.spines['left'].set_position('zero')
# add yticks at 3/16 and -3/16+1/4
plt.yticks([0,3/16, -3/16+1/4, 1/4], ['0', '3/16', '-3/16+1/4', '1/4'])
plt.xticks([0, 50], ['0', '$ →  \infty$'])
plt.legend();
